org.obrel.type

Class MetaTypes

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.obrel.type.MetaTypes

  • @Annotations.RelationTypeNamespace(value="")
public class MetaTypes
extends java.lang.Object
    This class contains definitions of standard meta-relation types. Relations with meta-types contain information about the objects they are set on. These objects are often other relations which are annotated with meta relations to further define their structure or behavior. For example, a meta-relation with the type MODIFIED indicates whether a certain object (e.g. a relation) has been modified or not. How such a relation is set depends on the respective application although some of the standard types are already supported by the object relations framework.

    It is recommended that applications use the standard types defined in this class if applicable to increase the interoperability of relation-based code because using standard types allows library code and tools to access and display such relations in a standard way.

    • Field Detail

      • DECLARING_CLASS

        public static final RelationType<java.lang.Class<?>> DECLARING_CLASS
        The class that declares the target type. Used for relations type to record the class in which they are declared. FINAL as this will never change after the initial declaration.

      • DECLARED_RELATION_TYPES

        public static final RelationType<java.util.List<RelationType<?>>> DECLARED_RELATION_TYPES
        The relation types that have been declared in a class, in the order in which they are declared. References to relation types from other contexts like StandardTypes are also included. Types with the modifier PRIVATE are excluded. FINAL as this list will never change after the initial declaration.

      • DATATYPE

        public static final RelationType<java.lang.Class<?>> DATATYPE
        The datatype class of a certain element; this type is final because it is intended to define a datatype that doesn't change.

      • ELEMENT_DATATYPE

        public static final RelationType<java.lang.Class<?>> ELEMENT_DATATYPE
        The datatype of elements in a collection or container.

      • KEY_DATATYPE

        public static final RelationType<java.lang.Class<?>> KEY_DATATYPE
        The datatype of keys in a map.

      • VALUE_DATATYPE

        public static final RelationType<java.lang.Class<?>> VALUE_DATATYPE
        The datatype of values in a map.

      • DECIMAL_PRECISION

        public static final RelationType<java.lang.Integer> DECIMAL_PRECISION
        The precision of a decimal value. Typically used in conjunction with DECIMAL_SCALE.

      • DECIMAL_SCALE

        public static final RelationType<java.lang.Integer> DECIMAL_SCALE
        The scale of a decimal value. Typically used in conjunction with DECIMAL_PRECISION.

      • OBJECT_ID_ATTRIBUTE

        public static final RelationType<java.lang.Boolean> OBJECT_ID_ATTRIBUTE
        Marks a relation type that defines an object identifier.

        Marks a relation type that defines an object type.

        public static final RelationType<java.lang.Boolean> OBJECT_NAME_ATTRIBUTE
        Marks a string relation type that refers to an object's name.

        public static final RelationType<java.lang.Boolean> PARENT_ATTRIBUTE
        Marks a relation type that represents the parent in a hierarchy.

      • CHILD_ATTRIBUTE

        public static final RelationType<java.lang.Boolean> CHILD_ATTRIBUTE
        Marks a relation type that represents the children in a hierarchy.

      • IMMUTABLE

        public static final RelationType<java.lang.Boolean> IMMUTABLE
        Marks an element to be immutable. This is an "active" relation type that will prevent any further modifications of the relations of the target object after a relation with this type has been set. This type can only be set to TRUE, trying to set it to FALSE will cause an exception.

        The immutable state is applied to all relations of the target object, thus preventing any further modifications of the relation target and meta-relations. If the target object of this relation type implements the interface Immutability the object will be set to be immutable by invoking the corresponding interface method.

        The immutability enforced by this type only prevents the modification of the relations themselves, not of their target value objects. These must be handled separately by the application code if necessary. The only exception are relation types that have a generic collection interface as their target type (i.e. List, Set, or Map). These will be converted to immutable collections with the corresponding methods of the Collections class.

        If this type is used on objects that contain fields besides their relations or are not relatable at all it is also the responsibility of the application to implement the corresponding behavior. This can be done by either checking for a relation with this type or by implementing the Immutability interface.

      • MANDATORY

        public static final RelationType<java.lang.Boolean> MANDATORY
        Marks an object to be mandatory; the reverse can be expressed with the type OPTIONAL. It should be evaluated carefully whether an application marks objects as mandatory or as optional by default. Both approaches can be reasonable depending on the respective use case.

      • OPTIONAL

        public static final RelationType<java.lang.Boolean> OPTIONAL
        Marks an object to be optional. See the documentation of the relation type MANDATORY for details.

      • ORDERED

        public static final RelationType<java.lang.Boolean> ORDERED
        Marks an object to have a certain kind of order (e.g. a ordered map).

      • MANAGED

        public static final RelationType<java.lang.Boolean> MANAGED
        Marks an object by some other object. This flag is final because managed objects are considered to be owned by the managing instance.

      • INDEXED

        public static final RelationType<java.lang.Boolean> INDEXED
        Marks a relation target to being indexed in some way; the exact definition of the indexing is up to the application code using this flag.

      • UNIQUE

        public static final RelationType<java.lang.Boolean> UNIQUE
        Marks a relation target to be unique in a certain context; the definition of this context is up to the application code using this flag.

      • MODIFIED

        public static final RelationType<java.lang.Boolean> MODIFIED
        Marks an object that has been modified.

      • LOCKED

        public static final RelationType<java.lang.Boolean> LOCKED
        Marks an object as locked. This is only a declarative type. How the locking is implemented must be determined in the using application.

      • INVALID

        public static final RelationType<java.lang.Boolean> INVALID
        Marks an object to be invalid.

      • CLOSED

        public static final RelationType<java.lang.Boolean> CLOSED
        Marks an object that has been closed, typically as an implementation of the Closeable interface.

      • AUTOGENERATED

        public static final RelationType<java.lang.Boolean> AUTOGENERATED
        Marks an object that is generated automatically.

      • INTERACTIVE

        public static final RelationType<java.lang.Boolean> INTERACTIVE
        Marks an object that is interactive, e.g. in a user interface.

      • INITIALIZING

        public static final RelationType<java.lang.Boolean> INITIALIZING
        Can be used to mark objects during their initialization phase.

      • INITIALIZED

        public static final RelationType<java.lang.Boolean> INITIALIZED
        Can be used to mark objects that have been fully initialized. This type has the flag FINAL which means it can only be assigned once because objects with this flag are intended to remain in that state.

      • AUTHENTICATED

        public static final RelationType<java.lang.Boolean> AUTHENTICATED
        A flag that indicates that an authentication has been performed successfully.

      • AUTHORIZED

        public static final RelationType<java.lang.Boolean> AUTHORIZED
        A flag that indicates that the target is authorized to perform certain actions.

      • HIERARCHICAL

        public static final RelationType<java.lang.Boolean> HIERARCHICAL
        Marks an object or relation that is hierarchical, i.e. an element in a hierarchy of objects.

      • TRANSACTIONAL

        public static final RelationType<java.lang.Boolean> TRANSACTIONAL
        Marks an object to be evaluated in a transactional context. This must not be confused with objects that implement the Transactional interface. The latter implement transaction handling while objects marked with this flag can be surrounded by transaction, e.g. because they create or execute transactional elements.

      • SORT_DIRECTION

        public static final RelationType<de.esoco.lib.property.SortDirection> SORT_DIRECTION
        Defines the sort direction on the annotated element.

      • RELATION_TYPE_NAMESPACE

        public static final RelationType<java.lang.String> RELATION_TYPE_NAMESPACE
        The namespace of a relation type. This meta type is only intended to be used by frameworks that need to modify the namespace of certain relation types. Other code should either rely on the default namespace or use the annotation Annotations.RelationTypeNamespace to define a different namespace for a class.

      • RELATION_TYPE_INIT_ACTION

        public static final RelationType<Action<RelationType<?>>> RELATION_TYPE_INIT_ACTION
        An optional initialization action for relation types that if set on a relation type will be invoked after a relation type has been initialized by the framework. After the initialization this meta-relation will be deleted from it's relation type. The initialization will only be invoked for relation types that are initialized globally through the framework method RelationTypes.init(Class). It can be used to establish additional constraints on certain relations types, e.g. special namespaces.

      • ERROR_HANDLING

        public static final RelationType<de.esoco.lib.property.ErrorHandling> ERROR_HANDLING
        A generic error handling mode that can be set on objects supporting it.
